title: From Getting Around at Home to Getting Lost in Canada: My Navigation Story
text:
Moving to a new country changes everything‚Äîincluding how you find your way around. My journey from Ghana to Canada taught me that navigation isn‚Äôt just about maps and directions. It‚Äôs about feeling at home in a new place.


Back home in Ghana, I never needed GPS. Getting around was easy and natural. Every neighborhood had its own personality‚Äîunique buildings, familiar shops, and streets that felt different from each other. Finding places meant looking for landmarks everyone knew: ‚ÄúTurn at the red building,‚Äù ‚ÄúStop at the corner shop,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs three houses past the tall fence.‚Äù
This way of navigating worked because I grew up there. I knew the stories behind every street corner. Every building meant something. GPS wasn‚Äôt necessary when your surroundings felt like an old friend.



Arriving in the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) was like landing on a different planet. The first thing I noticed? All the houses looked exactly the same. Street after street of similar buildings, identical driveways, and matching fences. Where were the unique landmarks I was used to?
During my first few months, simple trips became major challenges. Going to the grocery store or meeting a friend required serious planning and memorization. Without the familiar visual cues from home, every journey felt like navigating through a maze where all the walls were identical.
I‚Äôll be honest‚Äîit was tough. Really tough.



Those first weeks meant constantly checking my phone for directions. Even short walks required GPS assistance. I became anxious about my phone battery dying or losing data connection. This dependency would have seemed crazy back home, but here it was survival.
But humans adapt. Slowly, I started recognizing patterns. Certain intersections became familiar. The subtle differences between shopping plazas started making sense. Bus stops turned from confusing waypoints into reliable landmarks. What looked like endless suburban sprawl gradually revealed its hidden character.



Canada‚Äôs digital navigation tools are lifesavers for newcomers like me. Apps for the TTC and other transit systems don‚Äôt just give directions‚Äîthey give confidence. They let you explore without fear of getting lost.
These apps do more than help you find places. They help you feel brave enough to discover new neighborhoods, try new restaurants, and navigate complex transit systems. When you know you can always find your way home, you‚Äôre more willing to explore.



What surprised me most is that even people who‚Äôve lived in Canada for decades use GPS apps regularly. Even those born and raised here pull out their phones when going somewhere new. The GTA is huge‚Äîover 7,000 square kilometers. No one person can know it all.
This shared reliance on technology creates an interesting situation. Whether you‚Äôre a newcomer from Ghana or a lifelong Toronto resident, exploring unfamiliar areas often requires the same digital help. GPS doesn‚Äôt just help immigrants adapt‚Äîit helps everyone navigate confidently.



The journey from constant GPS checking to knowing my way around took time. First, my work-to-home route became automatic. No more checking directions for that daily commute! Then familiar routes slowly expanded into broader knowledge of the area.
Each successful trip without GPS felt like a small victory. Building confidence in navigation mirrors other aspects of adapting to a new culture. Just like learning a new language through daily practice, understanding a new city‚Äôs geography comes through repeated exploration.



GPS technology does something important for newcomers‚Äîit removes one of the biggest fears about living in a new place: getting lost. When you know you can navigate safely, you‚Äôre more likely to explore, try new things, and gradually build the local knowledge that makes a place feel like home.
These apps serve as training wheels. They provide security while you develop the confidence and familiarity needed to eventually explore independently. GPS helps bridge the gap between feeling lost and feeling at home.



Today, I‚Äôve found a comfortable balance. Familiar routes flow naturally without any tech help‚ÄîI know my neighborhood like I once knew the streets of Ghana. For new destinations, I still rely on GPS, and that‚Äôs perfectly fine.
This mixed approach, combining growing local knowledge with digital tools, makes sense for modern urban life in Canada. The experience taught me that technology can help you adapt while building real confidence for independent living.



My navigation journey highlights something important: technology can bridge cultural experiences. It enables adaptation while preserving the confidence necessary for truly making a new place home. Whether you‚Äôre discovering your first Canadian neighborhood or exploring a distant part of the city, GPS ensures every journey can be undertaken with confidence.
In a country as big as Canada, digital navigation isn‚Äôt just convenient‚Äîit‚Äôs essential. It‚Äôs what makes urban exploration and cultural discovery possible, helping any place eventually feel like home.
The funny thing is, after all this adaptation, I now know my local routes so well that I walk and take buses without any map assistance. But step outside my familiar area? You bet I‚Äôm pulling out that GPS app like everyone else.

For newcomers to Canada, apps like Google Maps, Citymapper, and local transit apps are invaluable during those first months. They don‚Äôt just help you get around‚Äîthey help build the confidence you need to make your new city feel like home.

title: Behind the Scenes: My Journey as a Digital Alchemist at Northeastern University‚Äôs Global Symposium
text:
When I first received the opportunity to serve as one of the organizers for the 2025 Northeastern University Global Symposium on Leadership & Project Management, I had no idea how transformative this experience would become. What started as an invitation to contribute to a prestigious academic gathering evolved into a masterclass in collaboration, digital strategy, and the art of bringing together brilliant minds from around the world.


As the self-proclaimed ‚Äúdigital alchemist‚Äù of our organizing team, my role encompassed far more than I initially anticipated. From crafting compelling email campaigns for participants and managing social media announcements for our stellar lineup of spotlight speakers, every day brought new challenges and opportunities to learn. The digital landscape of academic event management proved to be a fascinating blend of strategic communication, technical coordination, and relationship building.
The symposium, scheduled for August 21-22, 2025, served as a premier gathering of thought leaders, industry experts, and scholars dedicated to advancing leadership and project management. Being part of the team that made this vision a reality was both humbling and exhilarating.



None of this would have been possible without the instrumental support of Dr.¬†Behnaz Merikhi, whose belief in my potential opened doors I never imagined could be within reach. Dr.¬†Merikhi, an Assistant Teaching Professor in the Master of Professional Studies in Informatics program at Northeastern University, Toronto, brings a wealth of expertise with her PhD in Electrical and Computer Engineering from Concordia University. Her academic excellence is matched only by her generous mentorship spirit.
Dr.¬†Merikhi didn‚Äôt just provide an opportunity; she created a bridge to connect with Northeastern‚Äôs prestigious faculty network. Her guidance throughout this journey has been invaluable, and I‚Äôm deeply grateful for her faith in my abilities to contribute meaningfully to such a significant academic endeavor. You can connect with Dr.¬†Merikhi and learn more about her groundbreaking work in informatics and network optimization through her Northeastern University faculty profile.



Working alongside Northeastern‚Äôs distinguished faculty taught me that academic excellence thrives on genuine collaboration. Each email strategy session, each social media campaign, and each coordination meeting revealed the meticulous planning and passionate dedication that go into creating a world-class symposium. The faculty members I had the privilege to work with demonstrated not only their expertise in leadership and project management but also their commitment to fostering the next generation of professionals in these fields.
The experience of managing participant communications taught me the delicate balance between professionalism and warmth that‚Äôs essential in academic outreach. Every message we sent represented not just information, but an invitation to be part of something larger ‚Äì a global conversation about the future of leadership and project management.



The role of ‚Äúdigital alchemist‚Äù became a perfect metaphor for what we accomplished together. Like ancient alchemists who sought to transform base materials into gold, our team transformed ideas, schedules, speaker profiles, and logistical details into engaging digital content that attracted participants from around the globe. Whether it was crafting the perfect subject line for a participant email or timing social media announcements for maximum engagement, every digital touchpoint was an opportunity to create something valuable.
The spotlight speaker announcements were particularly rewarding to manage. Seeing the excitement build across social platforms as we revealed each distinguished speaker reminded me of the power of strategic digital communication in the academic world.



The symposium has concluded, and what an extraordinary gathering of minds it turned out to be! Witnessing months of strategic planning come to fruition was deeply rewarding. The experience as part of the organizers to the event has been more than educational ‚Äì it‚Äôs been transformational. Working with Northeastern University‚Äôs exceptional faculty, collaborating with fellow organizers, and contributing to an event that impacted leaders and project managers globally has been a privilege I‚Äôll carry with me throughout my career.
To everyone who joined us for the 2025 Global Symposium on Leadership & Project Management, thank you for validating the months of passionate work, strategic planning, and collaborative effort our team invested in creating an experience worthy of your expertise and engagement.



This journey has reinforced my belief that the most meaningful professional experiences come from the relationships we build and the mentors who believe in our potential. Dr.¬†Behnaz Merikhi‚Äôs support exemplifies the best academic mentorship ‚Äì generous, visionary, and deeply committed to student success.
To my lead organizers, the faculty members who welcomed me into their planning processes, and the participants who made the symposium a success: thank you for allowing me to be part of something truly special.

The 2025 Northeastern University Global Symposium on Leadership & Project Management took place on August 21-22, 2025. For more information, visit pmsymposium.cps.northeastern.edu. You can also view my profile at the symposium website pmsymposium.cps.northeastern.edu/kwabena-asante

title: From Customer Service to AI Explainability: Why SHAP Matters in the Real World
text:
Working as a customer service representative at Freedom, where I handled credit checks and customer inquiries, taught me one of the most valuable lessons of my career: people deserve to understand the decisions that affect their lives. Every day presented a familiar scenario that played out like clockwork across countless interactions.


The routine was predictable yet always carried an undercurrent of tension. A customer would approach, hopeful about their application. I‚Äôd run their credit check, watching the system process their financial history in real-time. The outcome was binary and immediate‚Äîeither the green light of approval accompanied by smiles and congratulations, or the red light of decline followed by disappointed faces and inevitable questions.
The most challenging part wasn‚Äôt delivering bad news; it was the aftermath. Without fail, declined customers would ask the question that haunted every interaction: ‚ÄúBut why was I declined?‚Äù Armed with nothing more than a system verdict and standard protocols, my response was frustratingly inadequate: ‚ÄúPerhaps there‚Äôs an issue with your banking information. You might want to contact your financial institution for clarification.‚Äù
This experience highlighted a fundamental problem in automated decision-making systems‚Äîthe opacity that leaves both customers and representatives in the dark about the reasoning behind critical financial decisions.



This frustration with black-box decision-making led me to discover SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a groundbreaking approach to machine learning interpretability. SHAP functions as a sophisticated translator between complex AI models and human understanding, providing detailed insights into why specific decisions are made.
Rather than simply rendering binary judgments, SHAP breaks down each prediction into comprehensible components. It illuminates how individual factors‚Äîpayment history patterns, debt-to-income ratios, historical financial behaviors, and even specific incidents like that late car payment from 2022‚Äîcollectively influence the model‚Äôs final decision. This granular analysis transforms impenetrable algorithmic decisions into transparent, understandable explanations.





The financial services industry thrives on trust, and transparency is its foundation. When institutions can provide specific, data-driven explanations for their decisions, they transform potentially frustrating experiences into educational opportunities. Instead of leaving customers to speculate about rejection reasons, banks can offer concrete feedback: ‚ÄúYour application was declined primarily due to recent late payments affecting 60% of the decision, combined with current debt utilization impacting 25% of the evaluation.‚Äù
This level of transparency doesn‚Äôt just improve customer satisfaction‚Äîit builds lasting relationships based on understanding rather than frustration.



In highly regulated sectors like finance and healthcare, algorithmic accountability isn‚Äôt just beneficial‚Äîit‚Äôs mandatory. Regulatory frameworks increasingly require institutions to demonstrate that their automated decision-making processes are fair, unbiased, and legally defensible. SHAP provides the analytical framework necessary to meet these requirements by offering detailed documentation of decision factors and their relative importance.
This capability becomes particularly crucial when addressing potential bias in lending practices, hiring decisions, or medical diagnoses, where unexplained algorithmic decisions can have serious legal and ethical implications.



For data scientists and machine learning engineers, SHAP offers invaluable diagnostic capabilities. It provides unprecedented visibility into model behavior, revealing when algorithms rely disproportionately on problematic features or exhibit unexpected patterns. This insight enables teams to identify and address issues like geographical bias in credit scoring or demographic disparities in approval rates before they impact real customers.




The technical implementation of SHAP is remarkably accessible, making advanced explainability techniques available to organizations of all sizes. The framework integrates seamlessly with existing machine learning workflows:
import shap
explainer = shap.Explainer(model, X_test)
shap_values = explainer(X_test)
shap.plots.waterfall(shap_values[0])
This simple code snippet can transform any compatible model into an explainable system, generating visualizations that clearly demonstrate how different factors contribute to individual predictions.



Reflecting on my customer service experience, I recognize that the frustration customers felt wasn‚Äôt just about being declined‚Äîit was about being denied understanding. Every ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why‚Äù response represented a missed opportunity to educate, guide, and maintain trust.
SHAP addresses this fundamental gap by ensuring that AI-driven decisions come with built-in explanations. When customers understand not just what happened but why it happened, they‚Äôre empowered to take informed action. They can address specific financial behaviors, understand the factors that matter most, and work strategically toward future approval.



As artificial intelligence becomes increasingly prevalent in decisions that affect people‚Äôs lives‚Äîfrom loan approvals and medical diagnoses to job applications and insurance rates‚Äîthe need for explainability grows more critical. Organizations implementing AI systems have a responsibility to ensure their decisions are not just accurate but also transparent and fair.
For those developing machine learning models that impact human lives, incorporating explainability tools like SHAP isn‚Äôt just a technical enhancement‚Äîit‚Äôs an ethical imperative. Because in a world where algorithms make increasingly important decisions about our lives, everyone deserves to understand the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind the answer.
The journey from frustrated customer service representative to AI explainability advocate has taught me that the most powerful algorithms are those that not only make good decisions but can also explain them clearly. SHAP doesn‚Äôt just tell the story of algorithmic decision-making‚Äîit ensures every chapter is transparent, understandable, and actionable.

For those interested in exploring SHAP implementations, the official GitHub repository provides comprehensive documentation and examples. Additionally, Towards Data Science offers excellent tutorials on practical SHAP applications in real-world scenarios.
